results.title: Yodit and I
results.creator_credit: Duaa Mahmoud, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A tale of heroic acts of a mother’s quest to return her son safe and sound from the battlefields of East Africa in 1896. This inspiring story of Yodit, now half legend, stays alive as it is passed down from one generation to the next.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Duaa Mahmoud, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Sad realisation
results.creator_credit: Vivian Tran, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The sight of ugly bare land and the sound of heavy machinery where once stood a forest of trees are all too real for Vivian Tran to block out. Trees cannot protect themselves against being logged. A poignant story.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vivian Tran, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Second reality
results.creator_credit: Stacey Fischer, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Always on the move, changing schools, losing new friends, Stacey Fischer escaped from the real world of loneliness to a world where she could create people who couldn’t leave - a place where she would be safe.

results.title: My first year
results.creator_credit: Louise Bryant, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Louise shares her experiences and the three most important lessons she learnt in her first year as a secondary teacher. These are the things they don’t teach you at uni; survival, rewards and pleasant surprises.

results.title: Play It Again II: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990’s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. Funding comes from the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on preserving Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.

Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on preserving Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.

production_dates.notes: Games in this Collection date from the 1990s. The ARC research project "Play It Again" (II) will be completed in 2022.

results.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen [DOS]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, registration card and installation guide in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Flight of the Amazon Queen is a point and click adventure where you play Joe King as he uses his plane, the Amazon Queen, to fly famous actress Faye Russell to a film shoot. When the plane crash lands in a remote jungle, and he must use his wits to battle his way out of the dangers he faces.

As with many point and click adventures, a set of icons at the bottom of the screen allows the player to interact with other characters or the environment. The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.
results.description:

As with many point and click adventures, a set of icons at the bottom of the screen allows the player to interact with other characters or the environment. The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.
